import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline

source.b819ab12:
# Univariate Analysis
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (20, 10)
sns.countplot(train_data['department'], color='pink')
plt.title('Different departments in the company', fontsize=30)
plt.xlabel('Department names', fontsize=18)
plt.ylabel('Count', fontsize=18)
plt.show()
source.d16d6152:
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (20, 10)
sns.countplot(train_data['region'], color = 'pink')
plt.title('Different Regions in the company', fontsize = 30)
plt.xticks(rotation = 60)
plt.xlabel('Region Code', fontsize = 15)
plt.ylabel('count', fontsize = 15)
plt.show()

plt.ylabel('Count')
plt.show()

labels=('KPIs not met','KPIs met')

source.670706a3:
data = pd.crosstab(train_data['department'], train_data['is_promoted'])
data.div(data.sum(1).astype(float),axis=0).plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, figsize=(20,10), color=['blue','pink'])

plt.title('Departments and promotion', fontsize = 30)
plt.xlabel('Different Departments of the Company', fontsize = 15)
plt.legend()
plt.show()

plt.legend()
plt.show()

source.b93c4e1e:
data = pd.crosstab(train_data['awards_won?'], train_data['is_promoted'])
data.div(data.sum(1).astype(float),axis=0).plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, figsize=(10,7), color=['blue','pink'])

plt.title('Dependency of awards won in promotion', fontsize = 30)
plt.xlabel('Awards won or not', fontsize = 15)
plt.legend()
plt.show()
source.77e95be3: department with max people is sales and marketing
source.5977aee3: ### There is not a significant difference in promotion based on level of education
source.770373cf: ### The company promotes employees of all the ages equally even the freshers have equal share of promotion and also the senior citizen employees are getting the equal share of Promotion in the Company
source.ca9d6171: Highest number of people are from region 2
source.4c24ba0f: ### We can see that there is an equal development in each departments of the company
source.cb3e14e3: ### It is clearly seen that employees with better KPIs have better chance at promotion
source.af790850: ### Promotions are almost equal but employees with more than 32 years are more likely
source.cb33a68c: ### There is no biasedness in promotion based on recruitment channel
source.8cd9bb08: ### The chances of promotion significantly increases with high Training Score.
source.764e7944: ### There is a very good chance of getting promoted if the employee has won an award
source.dfc88589: ### We can see that the chances of getting promoted increase significantly with better previous year rating.
source.c841bb08: ### Both the genders have equal chances for promotion
source.148f61cb: ### The above graph shows that there is no biasedness over regions in terms of Promotion as all the regions share promotions almost equally.
source.77514017: ### We can see in the figure that with increasing no of training, promotion decreases but the correlation is not perfectly clear.
